Situation1: They interact warmly with a long line of shoppers during a busy lunch hour.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: The lunch rush at the grocery store is always intense, but today feels especially overwhelming. As a cashier, I’m expected to keep the line moving and greet each customer with a smile, even as the register beeps nonstop and the line snakes past the bakery. I do my best, chatting with regulars and apologizing for the wait, but my mind keeps drifting to the voting booth set up in the corner of the store. I finally get my break and hurry over, ballot in hand, eager to do my civic duty. The poll worker examines my envelope and frowns, pointing out a smudge on my signature. “I need you to re-sign this, please,” she says, her tone firm. I glance back at the clock, knowing my break is almost over and the line at my register is only getting longer. I feel torn—my manager expects me to be back on time, customers expect quick service, but as a voter, I’m supposed to follow every instruction to make sure my vote counts. My heart pounds as I stand there, caught between the demands of my job and my responsibility as a citizen, unsure which expectation I should meet first.
